image.altText: The Robodebt royal commission report handed to the federal government

items.synopsis: Unnamed individuals will be referred for criminal and civil prosecution after a royal commission handed down its report into the unlawful Robodebt scheme today.

title.children: Commissioner brands Robodebt 'extraordinary saga' of 'venality, incompetence and cowardice'

image.altText: A man in a checked shirt leans on a farm gate

items.synopsis: The departure of a South Australian MP from the Liberals left internal party fights playing out in public once again. Recent events within the party paint a bigger picture of where the SA Liberals is heading, writes Leah MacLennan.

title.children: 'Dark forces' and the push to the right: What a defection signals for the future of South Australian Liberals

image.altText: A judge handing an Indigenous man documentation.

items.synopsis: The Federal Court recognises Ngadjuri people as the native title holders of 15,000 square kilometres encompassing Burra, Clare and Orroroo.

title.children: Ngadjuri people celebrate 'brighter future' with native title win in SA's mid north

image.altText: Scene from shooting

items.synopsis: Police say two burnt-out cars have been discovered nearby after a shooting at a Marrickville business this afternoon.

title.children: Two men shot in 'targeted' attack at Sydney hair salon, two burnt-out cars found nearby

image.altText: Ross Fox wearing a dark business suit, sitting at a small with four energetic school students writing in their notepads.

items.synopsis: Universities will be given two years to overhaul their education degrees or risk losing their accreditation as part of a national bid to fix Australia's teacher shortage.

title.children: Dissatisfied with university teaching degrees, Ross retrained more than 1,000 teachers. The results were huge

image.altText: A teenager in Balgo poses with her hands in piece signs near the dam.

items.synopsis: Last summer, feuding between different groups in the Western Desert town of Balgo saw brawls break out in the streets. But an innovative new youth program has helped turn things around.

title.children: How a town lowered burglary and theft by 75 per cent

image.altText: A dog sitting on a beach, looking happy.

items.synopsis: The four-year-old Australian shepherd was reported missing after an alleged break-in at Southport earlier this week.

title.children: Bowie the blind dog found safe and well 300km from Gold Coast home

image.altText: Jamie Kah smiles, in jockey outfit as she rides a horse at Flemington Racecourse.

items.synopsis: Racing authorities accuse Jamie Kah and two others of breaching the sport's rules over pictures showing them with a white powder.

title.children: Top jockey Jamie Kah charged by racing stewards over 'white powder' images

image.altText: Mitch Marsh closes his eyes as he holds his bat and helmet up

items.synopsis: It came out of nowhere and ended just as abruptly, but Mitch Marsh's incredible century proved critical on a day that England found new Ashes life in some Mark Wood thunderbolts, writes Dean Bilton.

title.children: Mitch Marsh likely thought he would never make another Ashes ton … let alone one like this

image.altText: A young girl with red hair tucked into bed, lying on her side and blowing her nose.

items.synopsis: The number of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) cases have jumped close to 10 times higher in some states across Australia when compared to last year. Experts say COVID complacency and higher testing rates could be why.

title.children: RSV cases skyrocket across the country compared to same time last year

image.altText: A teenage girl

items.synopsis: A new licence class for people who drive ultra high-powered vehicles is among a suite of changes to be introduced by the South Australian government, following a campaign by the family of a teenager who was fatally struck by a Lamborghini.

title.children: Road rule changes to be introduced in SA in response to fatal Lamborghini crash

image.altText: A man wearing a green and yellow shawl leans over a grave while holding a photo of his son.

items.synopsis: Baruch's only son was suddenly killed in military action. Now he's fighting for permission to use his son's sperm to create a grandchild.

title.children: Baruch is so desperate to be a grandparent, he is fighting for a child to be born with 'planned orphanhood'

image.altText: David MacPhail outside Warrnambool Magistrates' Court in 2022.

items.synopsis: Judge John Smallwood told the court the ruling was made "as no jury, properly instructed" could find Senior Constable David MacPhail guilty.

title.children: Judge stops trial, acquits veteran police officer of assault

image.altText: An artist impression of the James Webb Space Telescope.

items.synopsis: The CEERS 1019 black hole existed more than 570 million years after the Big Bang, but it's much smaller than its peers.

title.children: James Webb Space Telescope's latest find 'difficult to explain', says NASA

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt kneels down beside a boy in a wheelchair

items.synopsis: When Kununurra automotive mechanic Mick Scott turned his hand to fixing a specialist wheelchair, he helped save a young boy's holiday in the process.

title.children: How this outback mechanic salvaged Cooper's Kimberley trip

image.altText: Dog in a cages at a pound.

items.synopsis: The RSPCA's chief executive says the "fierce opposition" to an upgrade at its Katoomba animal shelter has been "staggering" and staff members have been abused on the streets of the Blue Mountains town.

title.children: 'Conspiracy theory' and abuse from hostile community behind animal shelter closure, RSPCA says

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses walks out of the Melbourne Magistrates' Court.

items.synopsis: A County Court judge says Kumuthini Kannan's attempt to prevent a woman she had enslaved in her Melbourne home from giving evidence in court struck at the heart of the justice system, as she is sentenced to another year behind bars.

title.children: Melbourne woman convicted of slavery handed more jail time over bid to intimidate victim

image.altText: A young Indigenous man skydiving with a young woman. The man is smiling and gesturing to Uluru, pictured below.

items.synopsis: Skydiving isn't always how Marley imagined he'd get his kicks, but ever since he was a kid, he's been chasing the thrill.

title.children: Struggling with drugs and alcohol, Marley was given a birthday gift that would change the course of his life

image.altText: Peter Dutton smiles during first press conference as Opposition Leader.

items.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is ramping up calls for nuclear power in Australia, arguing reactors could be built on the sites of coal-fired power stations.

title.children: Peter Dutton opting for the nuclear option for Australia's energy future

image.altText: A police officer in uniform and a figure in a full-body white forensics suit stand by a police screen.

items.synopsis: A 20-year-old New South Wales man has been jailed for 14-and-a-half years for a murder committed in broad daylight in a Canberra alleyway in December 2021.

title.children: NSW man sentenced to more than 14 years' jail for daylight murder in Canberra CBD sparked by drug dispute

image.altText: A screenshot showing Australian cricketers walking through the Lord's Long Room, with Usman Khawaja talking to a member.

items.synopsis: Fans in the Long Room at Lord's will face movement restrictions and more space between them and players as the MCC continues to investigate the explosive second Ashes Test.

title.children: MCC announces new restrictions for Lord's Long Room following second Ashes Test fallout

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The ASX has fallen by close to 2 per cent at the start of trade, following Wall Street's lead after strong labour market data out of the US increased the likelihood of a Federal Reserve rate hike to curb inflation. Follow live.

title.children: ASX suffers biggest daily loss since March after rate hike fears cause sharp losses on Wall Street

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you've been shocked by your rising insurance premiums, you might just put it down to rising inflation and the cost of living, but there's another key driver pushing it up. Insurance partner at KPMG, Scott Guse, says climate change is increasingly becoming a key reason for rising premiums. Climate change risk has been factored into insurance premiums for years, but the risk and associated costs are rising. In the wake of the world experiencing its hottest day on record this week, and the UN declaring an El Niño weather event, business presenter Alicia Barry spoke with Mr Guse about what it means for insurance premiums.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Insurance premiums are rising — and climate change is a big reason why

children.content: If you've been shocked by your rising insurance premiums, you might just put it down to rising inflation and the cost of living, but there's another key driver pushing it up.
Insurance partner at KPMG,
Scott Guse
, says climate change is increasingly becoming a key reason for rising premiums.
Climate change risk has been factored into insurance premiums for years, but the risk and associated costs are rising.
In the wake of the world experiencing its hottest day on record this week, and the UN declaring an
El Niño weather event, business presenter
Alicia Barry
spoke with Mr Guse about what it means for insurance premiums.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NAB will stop sending links in unexpected texts to its customers to protect them from scams and fraud. The bank says it's about 95% complete with removing links from being included in its unexpected texts, and aims to eradicate them entirely by the end of the month. "Our aim is to make it as simple as we can for customers to know whether a message from NAB is legitimate," NAB CEO Ross McEwan said "My advice is don't click on a link. If you get an unexpected text message that looks like it's from NAB and it contains a link, don't click on it. "We want to make it as hard as possible for these criminals to steal money from hard-working Australians." Last year the bank sent 112 million texts to customers, with many including links to notify customers when their account was about to be overdrawn, or a new debit card had been posted. Moving forward, NAB will replace the links with advice to direct customers to visit its website, log into its app, or call them to take specific action. NAB says it has a total of 64 projects underway to stop scams from impacting its customers and operations, and has seen a 29% reduction in reports of NAB-branded scams this year by working in conjunction with telecommunication providers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NAB to remove links in text messages to crack down on scams

children.content: NAB will stop sending links in unexpected texts to its customers to protect them from scams and fraud.
The bank says it's about 95% complete with removing links from being included in its unexpected texts, and aims to eradicate them entirely by the end of the month.
"Our aim is to make it as simple as we can for customers to know whether a message from NAB is legitimate," NAB CEO Ross McEwan said
"My advice is don't click on a link. If you get an unexpected text message that looks like it's from NAB and it contains a link, don't click on it.
"We want to make it as hard as possible for these criminals to steal money from hard-working Australians."
Last year the bank sent 112 million texts to customers, with many including links to notify customers when their account was about to be overdrawn, or a new debit card had been posted.
Moving forward,
NAB will replace the links with advice to direct customers to visit its website, log into its app, or call them
to take specific action.
NAB says it has a total of 64 projects underway to stop scams from impacting its customers and operations, and has seen a
29% reduction in reports of NAB-branded scams this year
by working in conjunction with telecommunication providers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yesterday, Reuters reported that PwC Australia had supplied its client Google with confidential information on tax laws, leaked by former PwC partner Peter Collins — the first time a company was directly linked to the scandal. Today, Uber and Facebook, owned by Meta, are the latest firms named in reports, with Neil Chenoweth writing in the Australian Financial Review that the tech giants set up new company structures based on PwC advice. The AFR reports that the Australian Tax Office was "shocked" at how quickly the companies, along with others, were able to restructure operations to get around new tax avoidance laws — thanks to the heads up provided by the confidential government information obtained by Peter Collins. Both Uber and Facebook, in statements to the newspaper, said they had no knowledge that the advice provided by PwC was based on improperly-obtained information. Earlier this week, PwC named and removed eight senior partners linked to the use of the confidential Treasury briefings, including former chief executive Tom Seymour. It followed the conclusion of an internal investigation, which delivered a scathing assessment of the consulting firm's former management. "The investigation identified a failure of leadership and governance to adequately address the matters, either at the time or whilst the matters were under investigation by the Tax Practitioners Board or Australian Taxation Office," the report said. "This enabled poor behaviours to persist with no accountability." You can watch the full report from Daniel Ziffer here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Uber, Facebook the latest companies named in PwC scandal reports

children.content: Yesterday,
Reuters reported that PwC Australia had supplied its client Google with confidential information
on tax laws, leaked by former PwC partner Peter Collins — the first time a company was directly linked to the scandal.
Today,
Uber
and Facebook, owned by
Meta
, are the latest firms named in reports, with
Neil Chenoweth writing in the Australian Financial Review
that the tech giants set up new company structures based on PwC advice.
The
AFR

reports that the Australian Tax Office was "shocked" at how quickly the companies, along with others, were able to restructure operations to get around new tax avoidance laws — thanks to the heads up provided by the confidential government information obtained by Peter Collins.
Both Uber and Facebook, in statements to the newspaper, said they had no knowledge that the advice provided by PwC was based on improperly-obtained information.
Earlier this week,
PwC named and removed eight senior partners
linked to the use of the confidential Treasury briefings, including former chief executive Tom Seymour.
It followed the conclusion of an internal investigation, which delivered a scathing assessment of the consulting firm's former management.

"The investigation identified a failure of leadership and governance to adequately address the matters, either at the time or whilst the matters were under investigation by the Tax Practitioners Board or Australian Taxation Office," the report said.
"This enabled poor behaviours to persist with no accountability."
You can watch the full report from
Daniel Ziffer
here:

image.altText: A drawing showing a pre-historic group of men, women and a baby, listening to a woman with red body-paint.

items.synopsis: A new scientific technique identifies a body interred in an impressive 5,000-year-old tomb on Spain's Iberian peninsula as a woman, giving new insights into gender roles we know "preciously little about".

title.children: Spain's 'Ivory Lady' challenges assumptions of prehistoric gender roles

image.altText: A gold decorated historical cannon, with a blue inlay

items.synopsis: A richly decorated cannon, stolen in 1765, is just one of 478 cultural objects the Dutch government will hand back to Sri Lanka and Indonesia.

title.children: Netherlands to return looted Asian artefacts, more than two centuries later

image.altText: A middle-aged Indigenous woman with long dark hair stands behind a lectern filled with microphones.

items.synopsis: Earlier, the government was putting much faith in "the vibe" to carry the Voice – a general appeal to righting the wrongs of the past and giving Indigenous people the opportunity to be heard. Now the government is desperate to arrest the slide, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: The new 'prime target' in government's battle to stop the slide in Yes vote

image.altText: Commuters pile on into a train carriage with open doors

items.synopsis: An investigation is launched into a major suspension of services on the Sydney train network after a signaller called in sick and a replacement could not be found.

title.children: Sydney Trains apologises for system chaos but government rules out fare-free day

image.altText: Flags

items.synopsis: FIFA announces that the Aboriginal, Torres Strait, and Māori flags will fly alongside Australian and New Zealand flags during the Women's World Cup.

title.children: FIFA to allow First Nations flags at Women's World Cup

image.altText: Torn pieces of paper forming the head shoulders and obscured faces of a doctor with a face mask and stethoscope

items.synopsis: Almost 730 registered health professionals were accused of inappropriate behaviour or sexual misconduct by patients in the last financial year, new figures reveal.

title.children: Hundreds of doctors and nurses are accused of sexual misconduct. It is an improvement on the year before

image.altText: Harry Mcwilliam

items.synopsis: The Central Coast community remembers Harry Mcwilliam as a "charming young man … adored by every person", as they mourn the 20-year-old who died working on Newcastle's John Hunter Hospital redevelopment this week.

title.children: Mum opens up home to Harry's friends so they can grieve together

image.altText: A smiling young woman, long brown curly hair, looks at baby in arms. Aboriginal dot painting circles on black behind them.

items.synopsis: This Birpai woman knows it is easy for mothers to get anxious when their baby is unsettled. Now a new initiative is helping both mum and bub stay calm.

title.children: Amy has a special way of soothing her newborn Ivy. It connects them to their land and ancestors

image.altText: A missing person poster of a Hispanic teenage boy, showing his name and a table with descriptive information.

items.synopsis: A few days after Rudolph "Rudy" Farias IV was found unconscious outside a Houston church, police say he and his mother had spent eight years maintaining the ruse he was a missing person.

title.children: 'Missing' man Rudy Farias spent eight years with his mother hiding his existence

image.altText: A man and a pregnant woman embrace in a vineyard.

items.synopsis: Daniel McJannett is charged with the murder of Matthew Berry, 37, who police have described as his "longstanding friend".

title.children: Man accused of murdering Gold Coast father named in court

image.altText: Liam Broady puts his hands to his ears on Centre Court at Wimbledon

items.synopsis: Stan Wawrinka set up what looms as a potentially epic showdown with Novak Djokovic and Australia's men recorded a trifecta of victories but the day belonged to the most unlikely of local British heroes as Centre Court erupted for a massive upset.

title.children: Murray mound? Make it Broady's boulder. Wimbledon erupts as local hope records huge upset on Centre Court
